author: Jenifer Langosch
title: Cardinals' Alex Reyes has partial tear in UCL | MLB.com
text:
MRI reveals partial UCL tear in Reyes' elbow Cards righty, No. 6 prospect in MLB, was set to pitch in World Baseball Classic Outlook: Reyes, RHP, STL 0:29 Alex Reyes posted a stellar 1.56 ERA over 12 appearances (five starts) for the Cardinals and has outstanding swing-and-miss stuff By Jenifer Langosch / MLB.com | @LangoschMLB | + 0 COMMENTS 
JUPITER, Fla. -- The unbridled hope that typically accompanies the opening of Spring Training wasn't omnipresent at Cardinals camp on Tuesday, as the team was instead left waiting for answers about the health of its top prospect. 
Alex Reyes , who entered camp with the opportunity to win a Major League roster spot, underwent an MRI exam on his right elbow, general manager John Mozeliak confirmed, after notifying the medical staff of discomfort in that area. Results from that exam are not expected to be officially announced until Wednesday, but MLB Network's Dan Plesac tweeted on Tuesday that the MRI showed a partial tear in Reyes' right ulnar collateral ligament, perhaps setting the stage for Tommy John surgery. The club has not confirmed the report. Not good news on the rt elbow of #STLCards Alex Reyes. MRI reveals partial tear in rt UCL. Not certain ..BUT ...TJ surgery looms. — Dan Plesac (@Plesac19) February 14, 2017 
"I'm concerned about Reyes," Mozeliak said. "Any time you send someone out for an MRI, it's concerning." 
"I don't like MRIs," added manager Mike Matheny. "There must be a significant reason to do it." 
• 5 questions Cardinals face as camp opens 
Indications that something was amiss with Reyes began in the morning when he dressed out of his workout clothes and left the complex. He returned shortly after but did not throw his scheduled bullpen session. As the Cardinals were wrapping up their first official workout, Reyes departed to undergo the additional testing. 
Reyes, 22, last experienced discomfort in that area in 2013, when he was diagnosed with an elbow strain. He made his season debut on June 20 that year. 
"Clearly, I'm hoping for the best," Mozeliak said. "Good or bad, we have to push. That's what we do." 
Regardless of whether the Cardinals envisioned Reyes breaking camp in the big league rotation, he was expected to be a key contributor in 2017. Ranked by MLBPipeline.com as the No. 6 prospect in baseball, Reyes debuted last August and added to the hype by showcasing an advanced arsenal of pitches. Top Prospects: Reyes, STL Top Prospects: Alex Reyes, RHP, Cardinals 2017 MLB.com Top Prospects: Alex Reyes' fastball sits in the mid-to-upper-90s comfortably 
The right-hander appeared in 12 games (five starts) for the Cardinals last season and posted a 1.57 ERA with 52 strikeouts in 46 innings. He was moved permanently to the rotation in mid-September and led the team to wins in each of his subsequent starts. 
Originally slated to pitch in the World Baseball Classic, Reyes had been named to the Dominican Republic's designated pitcher pool. 
"You never want somebody to walk in the first day [and deal with this]," Matheny said.
